awd_titl_txt: Phase I IUCRC Iowa State University: Center for Bioplastics and Biocomposites
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of the Center for Bioplastics and Biocomposites (CB2) is to improve the basic knowledge of the synthesis, processing, properties, and compounding of bioplastic and biocomposite materials, as well as to develop reliable material characteristics data for industrial partners and support large-scale industrial implementation of renewable materials. Sustainability is a rapidly growing aspect of technology, driven partially by social factors; however, many industries are struggling to effectively incorporate sustainability-related practices. CB2 creates new knowledge, materials, and processes for sustainable biobased plastics and composites. The vision of the center is to develop knowledge that will facilitate the production of an array of high-value products, including plastics, coatings, adhesives, and composites, from renewable feedstocks that are compatible with current industrial manufacturing systems and thereby promoting rural development as well as national growth. The center focusses on the development of jobs in the area of sustainable manufacturing, focusing on conversion of agricultural and woody crops to energy and materials which are crucial to lasting job creation in the United States.  The center also strives to support education and diversity through engagement of K-12 educators, supporting a NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU)  co-located at ISU and WSU where students participate in research on sustainable materials.

The mission of the Center for Bioplastics and Biocomposites (CB2) is to develop fundamental knowledge related to bioplastics and biocomposites, to dissemination research-based findings to industry to promote sustainability and to educate future scientists and engineers. The team of researchers includes experts from the fields of polymer processing, polymer chemistry, materials science, and biomass utilization. It combines a wide area of experience and expertise, allowing a well-rounded interdisciplinary approach. In addition, both participating institutions (Iowa State University and Washington State University) have state-of-the-art facilities for polymer processing and characterization to facilitate the development of a fundamental understanding of the influence of processing on the properties of biopolymers and composites.  Research focus and priority areas are determined by industry partners through a process developed by the industry partners to ensure the relevance to and positive impact on sustainable future industry development.  Individual projects are based on seed concepts generated by the center?s industry partners and ultimately defined through an interactive process between researchers and industry partners.  The projects are then mentored on a monthly basis by the industry partners, which serves as a model for technology transfer.

por.por_cntn:
Plastics are ubiquitous. While plastics have greatly increased our quality of life, setting the stage for advances in medical devices, food packaging, consumer goods, and electronics, there are growing reports how these engineered materials are leaving behind a concerning legacy. There are concerns regarding micro-plastics in many of today’s consumer goods and even food and beverage products. There are numerous reports about plastics in the oceans and how they impact marine life and our natural ecosystems. An estimated 600 billion paper and plastic cups are distributed worldwide, and most of these are not recyclable or compostable1. There is a growing concern among the companies using plastics and synthetic composites as their feedstock about the lack of their fit within a circular economy. Many of them have initiated projects to develop more ecofriendly materials, for example Starbucks and McDonald’s have joined together in an initiative to develop a totally recyclable and/or compostable cup solution that promotes a circular economy2. There is the general concern regarding the large amount of plastics that is simply sent to our waste management infrastructure (i.e. landfills) and the global impacts on countries that lack such infrastructures. In addition, there is the obvious issue of lack of sustainability for plastic derived from fossilized carbon.

The team of CB2, a National Science Foundation Industry University Collaborative Research Center (IUCRC), consisting of researchers from Iowa State University, Washington State University, the University of Georgia, and North Dakota State University, is working on developing novel plastics, coatings, and composites from renewable feedstocks, namely agriculture and forestry.  These materials are renewable, sourced from natural resources, and can be engineered to degrade at the end of life.  In addition, the team is developing fundamental knowledge regarding the mechanical behavior, processing requirements, costs, and life cycle assessment of these materials. These advances are necessary to develop a bioeconomy where renewable feedstocks are converted into benign and biodegradable bio-based polymers, chemical products, and composites that can be substituted for petroleum-based products. The chemical constituents of the renewable feedstocks favor a biorefinery, analogous to a petroleum refinery. Cellulose and hemicellulose, together, can yield sugars for production of biofuels and biopolymers in a biorefinery. Lignin can be used to formulate dispersants, binders, emulsifiers, stabilizers, and extenders. Low-molecular-weight extractives from these renewable feedstocks that include aromatic phenolic compounds, terpenes, fatty acids, waxes, and alkanes, can be converted into high-value products.

Some of the results of CB2 research are already available to consumers on common market places. For example, the center (together with the United Soybean Board and the USDA) funded a project that developed and commercialized fully biobased planting and self-fertilizing containers that can now be purchased from SelfEco through Walmart and Amazon. The horticulture containers, formulated using soy/corn meals, act as natural fertilizers and are degradable in the soil within one to two years and degradable in compost within six weeks. If adopted for wide-scale use, these containers could save the horticulture industry an estimated $44.2 million per year in fertilizer costs in the United States, while reducing the environmental damage from nutrient run-off.

Another outcome of the center, stemming from a collaboration among Ford Motor Company, Hyundai Motor Group, Diageo, ARaymond, and CB2, was a biobased composite that had superior strength, weight properties, and environmental benefit compared to traditional composites, allowing the automotive industry to manufacture more efficient vehicles and upcycling coproducts, namely agave fibers, from the adult beverage industry.

Other outputs contributing to a vision of bioeconomy built on renewable feedstocks include a novel and more economical production method for bio-based propylene using sugar-derived 1,2-propanediol and glycerol as feedstocks, production of low-cost lignin composite materials using lignin, advancing the technology to create a cost-competitive biobased substitute to ABS with tunable properties, and development of a simple method to convert commercially available PLA to strong and durable polymers like thermosets yet moldable and recyclable like thermoplastics called vitrimers.

Finally, the greatest outcome of the Center for Bioplastics and Biocomposites is the workforce development. This center has trained nearly 50 undergraduate and graduate students and Postdocs, and resulted in over 55 scholarly outputs that include refereed journal articles, conference presentations, book chapters, thesis/dissertations, IPs, and invention disclosures. These synergistic partnerships between researcher and business communities enabled by NSF IUCRCs are critical to reduce the detrimental effects of plastics on our environment and eventually build a biobased circular economy.

1 https://www.fastcompany.com/90202133/exclusive-starbucks-and-mcdonalds-team-up-to-rethink-cups

2https://news.starbucks.com/press-releases/mcdonalds-joins-starbucks-closed-loop-partners-to-end-cup-waste
